issues.title: Accuracy and Precision: Dec 11 sync up call with the design team
issues.author: marisolpalmero
issues.body:
**Action**: Marisol to review documentation from vendors, on product specification on accuracy/precision, power factor implementation.

The idea is to include as a question for the working group on next Monday call:

Vendors SHOULD document the sensor type, calibration
method, and the expected measurement precision, as these factors are
distinct from accuracy but influence interpretation of the reported data?

**Action**: based on this, we need to consider to include clarification/terminology in the draft(s)

some relevant text to consider:

- Accuracy

Describes how close a measured or estimated power value is to the true physical value.

Examples:

“±10% of the actual power consumption”

“Derived from model, low fidelity”

“Direct sensor measurement, high accuracy”

- Precision

Describes the granularity or repeatability of the measurement — e.g., number of digits, stability of repeated reads.

Examples:

A sensor that reads 100.1 W, 100.2 W, 100.1 W is precise.

But if the real consumption is 120 W, the readings are precise but inaccurate.


Some more reasoning:

- A dataset may have high precision, low accuracy (stable but wrong).
- Or high accuracy, low precision (on average right, but noisy).
- Operators need accuracy for carbon reporting and power budgets.
- Engineers need precision to troubleshoot variations or detect anomalies.

Could it be something also to consider under Terminology or specific section (suggested text, to be discussed!!)
*  Accuracy versus Precision

   In the context of Power and Energy Monitoring, this document uses the
   term "accuracy" to describe how close a reported measurement is to the
   true physical value. Accuracy may be based on direct sensor readings,
   learned models, historic data, or manufacturer specifications.
   The "data-source-accuracy" identity hierarchy captures the expected
   error bounds or fidelity category of the reported value.

   While accuracy describes closeness to the true value, it is distinct
   from "precision", which refers to the repeatability, granularity, or
   number of valid digits in a measurement. A measurement may be highly
   precise yet inaccurate (e.g., stable readings that are offset from the
   real value), or accurate on average but with low precision (e.g.,
   noisy measurements).

   The accuracy identities defined in this module characterize the source
   and expected error bounds of the reported measurement but do not, by
   themselves, define the precision of the underlying sensor or data
   representation. Systems implementing this module MAY expose additional
   metadata such as sampling resolution, number of significant digits, or
   sensor calibration information to describe precision where relevant.

Based on first action, consider to add a question to the WG:
The "accuracy-measured" category indicates that the value originates from
a physical sensor. Vendors SHOULD document the sensor type, calibration
method, and the expected measurement precision, as these factors are
distinct from accuracy but influence interpretation of the reported data.

comments.author: marisolpalmero
comments.body:
here  some references to argument the discussion with the WG:
I list here the conclusions and reference:
* Most Telecom Standards Don’t Publish Accuracy
* Telecom standards (ITU, ATIS) focus on methodology and comparability across test labs.
* They assume proper calibration and good measurement practice — but do not define a fixed instrument accuracy requirement.
* Only ETSI explicitly codifies this in the measurement procedure text.
* The standards (except ETSI) do not themselves publish numeric accuracy requirements for vendor figures.



1. ETSI ES 203 136 — Lab Measurement Accuracy ONLY (NOT operational sensors)
https://www.etsi.org/deliver/etsi_es/203100_203199/203136/01.02.01_60/es_203136v010201p.pdf

 Does NOT apply to operational embedded sensors.

 Does NOT specify accuracy for device-internal energy telemetry.

________________________________

2. IETF BMWG Power Benchmarking — Benchmarking ONLY, no sensor accuracy
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-bmwg-powerbench/

 Does NOT define accuracy or uncertainty of operational measurements.

________________________________

3. ITU-T L.1310 — Metrics and methodology, no instrument accuracy
https://www.itu.int/rec/T-REC-L.1310

Defines energy efficiency metrics & methods.

 No explicit numerical accuracy requirements.

________________________________

4. ATIS-0600015.03 — Measurement/reporting methods, no accuracy
https://shop.standards.ie/en-ie/standards/atis-0600015-03-2023-165739_saig_atis_atis_3330614/

Defines TEER metric and reporting.

 No instrument accuracy requirements.

________________________________

5. General Metrology Reference (Useful): ISO/IEC 17025
Defines calibration, uncertainty, traceability.
 Not specific to telecom equipment.

________________________________

6. Vendor Product Documentation — NONE publish measurement accuracy for embedded sensors

Cisco ISR 1000
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/products/collateral/routers/1000-series-integrated-services-routers-isr/datasheet-c78-739512.html
 Typical/max power only. NO accuracy.

Juniper MX301
https://www.juniper.net/content/dam/www/assets/datasheets/us/en/routers/mx301-universal-routing-platform-datasheet.pdf
 No accuracy.

Juniper PTX Power Planning
https://www.juniper.net/documentation/us/en/hardware/ptx10004/topics/topic-map/ptx10004-power-planning.html
 Calculations only. No sensor accuracy.

Arista 7050
https://www.arista.com/assets/data/pdf/Datasheets/7050S_Datasheet.pdf
 “Typical power per port”. No uncertainty.

Nokia 7750 SR
https://www.nokia.com/asset/i/207452/
 Power values are simulated (HPE Power Advisor). No accuracy.

Huawei AR Series
https://e.huawei.com/en/documents/others/4b9905a27fbe49e09d1fa68cbb5d3780
 Typical/max power. No accuracy.

Only power metering products publish accuracy:
Huawei Smart Power Sensor (has accuracy class)
https://solar.huawei.com/admin/asset/v1/pro/view/10b44cb3ac91489981d76e0f752b579c.pdf

Cisco Meraki MT40 Smart Power Controller (accuracy provided)
https://documentation.meraki.com/IoT/MT_-_Sensors/Product_Information/MT_Overviews_and_Datasheets/MT40_Datasheet_-_Smart_Power_Controller

 These are external sensors, NOT embedded NIC/ASIC/PSU measuring systems.

________________________________

FINAL CONCLUSION

→ No existing telecom standard defines accuracy/uncertainty for operational embedded power sensors.

→ No major vendor publishes accuracy/uncertainty for device-internal power telemetry.

→ ETSI ES 203 136 is the only standard specifying numeric accuracy—but ONLY for external lab instruments.

→ ITU-T, ATIS, IETF do NOT specify accuracy for operational measurements.

________________________________
